prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ebonite feed heat‑set". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Ebonfeed Heat-Set

’Twas inkle-dark, the resin-rubes
Did dribble-drab upon the slate;
All jitter-stoked were nibbling tubes,
And quavering feeds did grate.

“Beware the Heat-Set, child of steam!
The scald that warps the ebon bite!
Beware the blutter-blobber’s gleam,
And shun the molten microlight!”

He took his sacful goose-quill nib;
Long time the frimsy foe he sought—
So rested he by the gurgling bib,
And sipped a slush of thought.

And, as in murky mends he stood,
The Heat-Set, with its searing flame,
Came burbling through the brittle wood,
And inked as soon as came!

Splat! splat! and snap-a-crack!
The ripper nib went clip-clack-cleave!
He left it charred, and with a whack
He cooled the scorched-up feed.

“And hast thou quenched the Heat-Set fiend?
Come press thy pen on living page!
O frabjous day! Calam-complé!”
He jigged in scribblers’ rage.

’Twas inkle-dark, the resin-rubes
Did dribble-drab upon the slate;
All jitter-stoked were nibbling tubes,
And quavering feeds did grate.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "hollow grind on an O1 blade". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Hollow Grind on an O1 Blade

’Twas platen-bright, the belt-born breeze
Did whirr and whindle through the shade;
All flakery flew the iron flees,
As sparksome embers played.

“Beware the Hollowgrind, my smith!
The swooping dip, the gulching bite!
Beware the chatter-burr that kith
Where gritlings dance at night!

“Grip fast your faithful O1 bar,
And keep the temper, keen and true;
For steel will warp where heaters are,
And oil will hiss at you!”

He fired the forge with fizzle-flare,
And quenched the blade in swirling jade;
Then to the wheel he took with care
A hollow grind he made.

And as in aimful poise he stood,
The Hollowgrind came snarling nigh—
It whiffled through the belted wood
With screech and scalding cry!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The wheel-born song went blade-wise laid;
He steeled the edge and stropped it new,
A razor-keen cascade.

“O frabjous cut! Kaloo, kalade!”
He cried, his work at last displayed;
So rings the tale of skill and shade—
Hollow grind on an O1 blade.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "forged leaf scroll". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Forged Leaf Scroll

’Twas kilnish dusk, when brazzen wyrds  
Did clink and shimmer in the gloam;  
All grithered were the sallow birgs,  
And whisperfeys flew home.  

“Beware the Forged Leaf Scroll, my sprout!  
The inkrum gleams, the sigils bite!  
Beware the quench-quen ghoul, and shroud  
The scorchlit wraith of write!”  

He took his quillsome blade in hand;  
Long time the parchment foe he sought—  
So rested he by Brindle Sand  
And dreamt a thrindle thought.  

And, as in vexish muse he lay,  
The Forged Leaf Scroll, with glyphs aflare,  
Came prinkling through the mottled clay  
And twanged the sullen air!  

Tlak-slam! tlak-slam! and sparking whir!  
The quillsome blade went zip-zak-zee!  
He snatched the sheet, he cleft the blur,  
And scorched its runelry.  

“And hast thou rent the Scroll of Leaf?  
O frabjous quirk! O tattle-toy!”  
He capered through the lilic reef  
In boundish burl of joy.  

’Tis kilnish dusk, and brazzen wyrds  
Still clink and shimmer in the gloam;  
Though silenced be the haunted words,  
The whisperfeys fly home.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "kiln witness cone bend". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Kiln Witness Conebend

’Twas kilnish noon, the sagger stones  
Did crunk and crackle in the glaze;  
All claggy were the firedrones,  
And murple danced the blaze.  

“Beware the Conebend, child of clay!  
The tipward droop, the oozy glint!  
Beware the molten maw’s hooray,  
And shun the scorching squint!”  

He took his tongs of tempered brass;  
Long time the slipsome foe he sought—  
So slumped he by the stilter pass  
And pondered fiery thought.  

And, as in kilnish hush he knelt,  
The Conebend, swaying hot and white,  
Came corkle-bind through vapor melt,  
Its witness eyes alight!  

Ping! pang! went tongs of gleaming gold!  
Cram-flash and quenchful hiss of steam!  
He bent the Bend, its witness cold,  
And woke from kilnish dream.  

“O frabjous clay! Callay! Cahoo!”  
We sang, “the Conebend’s bane is done!”  
Now steady stands the kiln crew  
Till next firenight begun.  

’Twas kilnish noon, the sagger stones  
Still crunk and crackle in the glaze;  
All claggy keep the firedrones,  
And murple dims the blaze.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "lead type in a composing stick". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
LEAD TYPE IN A COMPOSING STICK

’Twas fontling, and the slithy sorts  
Did kern and clatter in the tray;  
All mimsy were the quadding quorts,  
And mome slugs pied the clay.  

“Beware the Macklegratch, my child!  
The jaws that bite, the races quick!  
Beware the hounding lock-up wild,  
And spurn the frumious quik!”  

He took his trusty composing stick;  
Long time the copy-trail he sought—  
So rested he by chase-form brick,  
And stood awhile in thought.  

And, as in inky proof he stood,  
The Macklegratch, with fiery yawn,  
Came burbling through the sluggy wood,  
And mackled as it brawn!  

One – two! One – two! And through and through  
His bodkin blade went snick-snick-snack!  
He left it dead, and with its head  
He galleyed bounding back.  

“Hast slain the Macklegratch? Huzzah!  
Come to my arms, my quoinish boy!  
O day of fonts! Callooh! Callah!”  
He chortled, slugged with joy.  

’Twas fontling, and the slithy sorts  
Did kern and clatter in the tray;  
All mimsy were the quadding quorts,  
And mome slugs pied the clay.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "urushi lacquer cure". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Urushiwocky

’Twas glomming, and the sticky sap  
Did glint and gutter in the gloom;  
All tacky were the lacquer laps,  
And nuri-fumes perfumed the room.  

“Beware the Urushiwock, my child!  
The gum that clings, the cure that bites!  
Beware the Mushi-murker wild,  
And dodge the fuming blight!”  

He took his sable brush in hand;  
Long time the cure-some foe he sought—  
So rested he by shōji tree,  
And mused awhile in thought.  

And, as in smouldry dreams he stood,  
The Urushiwock, with oozy claim,  
Came slimber-flopping through the wood,  
And hissed its gummy name!  

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The sable brush went snick-snack-snur!  
He flicked and flexed; the fiend was vexed,  
And set at last to cure.  

“And hast thou slain the Urushiwock?  
Come, spread thy wares, my gleeful boy!  
O radiant glaze! Kalack! Kalock!”  
He chortled in his joy.  

’Twas glomming, and the sticky sap  
Still glints and gutters in the gloom;  
Untacky now are lacquered laps,  
And polish gilds the room.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plum brown blueing bath". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Plum-Brown Blueing Bath

’Twas plum-brown blueing bath, and sleek  
Did munkle mugs and bribble;  
All drappling were the miro-creeks,  
And the sneetch spumed and scribbled.  

“Beware the Bubblenub, my dear—  
The pipes that ploon, the suds that slosh!  
Beware the scrub-scruffed Snafflesneer,  
And shun the splatter-wash!”  

She took her foamy brush in hand;  
Long time the burbling foe she sought—  
So rested she by Brindle-strand,  
And frothed a frolic thought.  

And, as in sundered suds she stood,  
The Bubblenub, with blottled gleam,  
Came flouncing through the scubberwood  
And glomped within the steam!  

One–two!  One–two!  And through and through  
Her bristly brusher whickered;  
She snicked the stubber, nick by nick,  
And all its clamors flickered.  

“Come splash, O splendid child of mine!  
Come clatter to my soapy hearth!  
O frabbish day!  Kaloo, kaline!”  
She planged in bubbly mirth.  

’Twas plum-brown blueing bath, and sleek  
Did munkle mugs and bribble;  
All drappling were the miro-creeks,  
And the sneetch spumed and scribbled.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "farewell at a platform". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Farewell at a Platform

’Twas gloamish-gree, the clackly rails
Did glimber-glam beneath the sky;
All steamy swirled the pufflet veils,
As mufflegongs waved bye.

“Beware the Partinglume, my dear!
The snuffle-sigh that chills the bone!
Beware the woozy whistle near
That bids a heart alone!”

She clasped her marbel-mittened hands,
He hugged his bag of snick-snap gear;
Long lingered they in lumpish stands
Till rumble rang the ear.

And, as in mistful hush they stayed,
The Partinglume with blustry stride
Came howling through the lantern shade,
Its iron cheeks wide-eyed.

Snuff-snark! Snuff-snark! The doory jaws
Gaped open with a clangy cry;
He slipped within its belchy maws
And blinked a last goodbye.

O plushish hush, the platform bare,
While dringle-bells went ding-a-dee;
Her teary grin still drifted there—
So closed the farenwellish spree.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ink brayer and chase". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Inkbrayer and the Chase

’Twas smudgele-morn, and soggy presses  
Did fribble-splotch along the ream;  
All splankered were the quoiny cresses,  
And braybirds crooned a scheam.

“Beware the Inkbrayer, my child,  
The gloopy gloop, the thud and drum!  
Beware the friskling Chase, and wild  
The clampish quoins that come!”

He took his spatly roller-staff;  
Long time the mottled blot he sought—  
So rested he by Quiregraph,  
And thoughtly thunk his thought.

And, as in verlig gloom he lurked,  
The Inkbrayer with quorks ablare  
Came sploshing through the puddled murk  
And slubbered printy air!

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The roller-staff went flump and flare!  
He splanked its hide; it printed skew;  
He left it drumming there.

Then up sprang shifty Chase in clamp,  
Its iron jaws went chunk and chock;  
He twirled his staff with brayer-stamp  
And thunked it block by block.

“O frabjous day! Callooh, callace!”  
He galumphed back in blottery grace.  
They set the forme, they locked the chase,  
And ran a glorious case.

’Twas smudgele-morn, and soggy presses  
Did fribble-splotch along the ream;  
All splankered were the quoiny cresses,  
And braybirds crooned a scheam.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "summit prayer flag". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Summit Prayer-Flag

’Twas flindergrey on snowlit spires,  
When whiffling winds began to brag;  
All shimber-shorn, the climber fires  
To plant the summit prayer-flag.

“Beware the Rumblewrath, my child!  
The ruck and rift that yawns below!  
Beware the skreekling ice-fang wild,  
And scud the slagborn snow!”

He strapped his cramponblade with care;  
Long time the highted foe he sought—  
Then rested by a glimber flare,  
And dreamt a thrimble thought.

And, as in numbled dreams he scaled,  
The Rumblewrath, with riving roar,  
Came skrindle-scar through sluicing hail,  
Its throat a blizzard’s core!

One two! One two! And through and through  
His pickelspike went click-clack-clag!  
He left it dead, and with its head  
He raised the prayer-wise flag.

“Hast smote the Rumblewrath? Huzzah!  
O frabjous peak! Calloo! Callag!”  
They chanted high to crystal sky  
Around the summit flag.

’Twas flindergrey on snowlit spires,  
And hushful hush lay on the crag;  
The world below, in moon-struck mires,  
Beheld the prayer-bound flag.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "luthier's soundpost setter". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Luthier’s Soundpost Setter

’Twas varnish-time, and sprucey shims  
Did gyre and whimple round the peg;  
All trember-taut were maple rims,  
While catgut hummed in leg.

“Beware the Setter, gentle child!  
The pinchy prongs, the tempered steel!  
Beware the f-hole’s cavern wild,  
Where lurking splinters squeal!”

He took his silver soul-saw bright;  
Long time the belly wood he scoured—  
Then paused beneath the lamplight’s white  
And pondered tone-empowered.

And, as in rosin dreams he stood,  
The Setter, sleek with copper jaw,  
Came slipping through the varnish’d wood  
And creaked a clang’rous caw!

One flip—two twist!  Ping-pling-plang-pong!  
The timbers thrilled with newborn song;  
He snugged it true, the post stood strong,  
The soundboard chimed along.

“O hast thou set the heart secure?  
Rejoice!” the beaming fiddles cry.  
“O frabjous tone! So bright, so pure!”  
He laughed in luthier-sky.

’Twas varnish-time, and sprucey shims  
Did gyre and whimple round the peg;  
All trember-taut were maple rims,  
And music filled the keg.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "night‑blooming cereus vigil". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Night-Blooming Cereus Vigil

’Twas star-thrum, and the dusky dunes  
Did shimmer-shuffle in the heat;  
All dreamsy were the cacto-runes,  
And dusk-wings drummed a beat.  

“Beware the Nocti-bloom, my dear!  
The scent that lulls the lanterned vale!  
Beware its thorn-wrapped arms that leer,  
And shun its moon-white veil!”  

He took his phosphor-flicker lamp;  
Long time his vigil-post he kept.  
So leaned he by a spiny ramp,  
And half-in waking slept.  

And as his drowsy pulse lay still,  
The bloom-beast, clad in silver dress,  
Burst forth upon the starlit hill,  
In petaled luminess!  

Soft-soft! Soft-soft! Through desert draught  
Its fragrance drifted, pale and sly;  
He drank the hush the blossom waft,  
Then watched it close and die.  

“O sniffsome grace! O wondrous night!”  
They cried when dawn uncurtained flame.  
“Your tale shall keep the bloom-ghost bright—  
We’ll whisper forth its name!”  

’Twas star-thrum, and the dusky dunes  
Did shimmer-shuffle in the heat;  
All dreamsy were the cacto-runes,  
And dusk-wings drummed a beat.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "modular synth patch spaghetti". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Modulawocky

’Twas flickery-night, and the ribboned looms  
Did sproing and wobble ’mid the racks;  
All glitchy were the boomish gnomes,  
And dribble-clips went clacks.

“Beware the Patchspaghetti, child!  
The knotted cords that hiss and hum!  
Beware the Cablewock, so wild,  
The clickschlop modulrum!”

He took his brave banana lead;  
Long time the noodle sound he sought—  
So rested he by VCO tree  
And tuned in feedback thought.

And, as in dronish dread he sat,  
The Patchspaghetti, with fuzz-flung groan,  
Came burbling through the eurorack,  
And zazzled as it moan!

One-two, one-two! and thru and thru  
His patchbay prongs went snicker-snack!  
He clipped and flipped, and with a zip  
Unknotted every jack.

“And hast thou slain the Patchspaghetti?  
Come plugful boy, thou bleeping joy!  
O modulay! Zyn-thes-i-ay!”  
He chortled in alloy.

’Twas flickery-night, and the ribboned looms  
Did sproing and wobble ’mid the racks;  
All glitchy were the boomish gnomes,  
And dribble-clips went clacks.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "cassette wow and flutter". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Cassettawow and Flutterband

’Twas humbly-hush in hi-fi dusk,
The tapelets twined in tinsellair;
All flutter-fraught the wowing musk
Spun hissy-wild and fair.

Beware the Wowfluff, chrome of tone!
The whirry-burr that bends the tune!
Beware the pinch-roll’s gummy moan,
The capstan’s curdled croon!

He took his bias-burnish blade;
Long time the wobble-fiend he sought—
So rested he by VU tree
And queued in feedback thought.

And, as in spooledish doubt he wound,
The Wowfluff, whoopling smooth yet sly,
Came warpling through the head-grot ground
And fluttered—flap!—nearby!

Tap-zip! Tap-zap! Through wow and warp
The bias-blade went snick-snick-snite!
He clipped its fringe and crimped its harp
And spliced it left from right.

“And hast thou slain the Wowfluff dread?
Re-wind, my joy-soaked boy, rewind!”
He crammed the reels, he bowed his head:
“High-fidelity we’ll find!”

’Twas humbly-hush in hi-fi dusk,
The tapelets twined in tinsellair;
No flutter-fraught, no wowing musk—
Pure signal streamed to air.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "opal play‑of‑color flash". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Opal Play-of-Color Flash

’Twas glimmertide, and the snorbling breeze   
Did gyre and gimble through the sky;   
All gabbled were the spherpting trees,   
While prism-shadows fly.   

“Beware the Opal-Flash, my dear!   
Its play-of-color, wild and rash!   
Beware the rizzle-rift you hear,   
That streaks a starry splash!”   

He seized his shimmer-shatter blade;   
Long time the glim-torn trail he tracked—   
So rested he beneath the jade,   
And dreamed in swirl and black.   

And as he mused in moon-moss shade,   
The Opal-Flash with spectral flare   
Came fuddling through the glim-glass glade,   
And spangled all the air.   

One, two! One, two! And whirligrew!   
The shimmer-sword went snicker-snack!   
He cleft it clean—each rainbow hue   
Leapt reeling from the crack.   

“O frabjous day! Callooh! Callash!”   
She cried and clasped him, brave and bold;   
They danced amid the prism-lash,   
Where night unspooled its gold.   

’Twas glimmertide, and the snorbling breeze   
Still gyred and gimbled through the sky;   
All gabbled yet the spherpting trees,   
While dawn winked opal-eye.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "peony ants at dawn". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Peony Ants at Dawn

’Twas peonydawn, and the antwing blights  
Did sprindle-scamper on the lawn;  
All dewdivine were the roseate lights,  
With peony ants at dawn.  

“Beware the Acryllaphage, my dear!  
The petal-graze, the venom-spill!  
Beware the Surflesnare that skulks so near,  
And shun the Mournful Mallowthrill!”  

He took his thornéd thistlebrand;  
Long time the amber spoor he sought—  
So rested he in fronded land  
And steeped himself in thought.  

And, lo! while drowsy-dim he stood,  
The Acryllaphage, with mandibles fair,  
Came burrow-burbling through the wood  
And scented up the air!  

Zip-zap! Zip-zap! went thistlebrand;  
Bloom-sap sprayed from husk to husk.  
He left it limp upon the sand  
And strode from out the dusk.  

“Hast slain the Acryllaphage, my sprout?  
Come clamber close, my chalice boy!  
O pollen-day! Keraffle shout!”  
He chortled, drunk with joy.  

’Twas peonydawn, and the antwing blights

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "oscilloscope lissajous bloom". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Oscilloscope Lissajous Bloom

’Twas biasglow, and the cathode sweeps  
Did gyre within the room;  
All clocky were the harmonic deeps,  
In oscilloscope lissajous bloom.  

“Beware the Aliashark, my child,  
The jitter-jaws that chirp and fuzz!  
Beware the burbling Crosstalk wild  
And the dreadful Overbuzz!”  

He took his phase-locked phaser blade;  
Long time the stutter-foe he sought—  
So rested he ’neath null-node shade  
And phased in thunkish thought.  

And, as in quivery pensivoo,  
The Aliashark, with squeal and blaze,  
Came whiffling through the raster-blue,  
And moded up its phase!  

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The phaser blade went tick-tack-tock!  
He snicker-snacked the alias, too,  
And clocked it off the block.  

“And hast thou slain the Aliashark?  
Scope-cheers, my brave, bright boy!  
O jitter-less day! Callooh! Cathark!”  
He chortled in his joy.  

’Twas biasglow, and the cathode sweeps  
Did gyre within the room;  
All clocky were the harmonic deeps,  
In oscilloscope lissajous bloom.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "civet note and drydown". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Civetnote and the Drydown

‘Twas muskinge-time, and civetnote  
   Did snuffle through the blend;  
All flummer’d were the valer-scopes,  
   And myrrhlings swirled on end.  

“Beware the Civetnote, my nose!  
   The snaffling musk, the feral bite!  
Beware the Rummy-oud, and shun  
   The rancid Patchou-night!”  

He primed his sniffish spritz in hand;  
   Long time the bouquet-foe he sought—  
So rested he by Citrus tree  
   And wafted wonder-thought.  

And, as in snifty dreams he stood,  
   The Civetnote, with whisker wild,  
Came pouncing through the mirthy wood,  
   All growliferous and riled!  

One whiff, two whuffs! The vial he snuffed,  
   The atomiser rang with flair!  
He tamed the beast; its musk released  
   Lay swirling on the air.  

“Oh scent of bloom! O sniffle-day!”  
   He chortled in his joy.  
He bound the note into the base,  
   Its savagery alloy.  

‘Twas drydown now; the amberdrowse  
   Lay velvet on the skin.  
All calmly were the sandal-boughs,  
   And peace perfumed within.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Reglet and Furniture

’Twas flimber-fent in Furnishbrook,  
The deskly drawers dreamt in wax;  
All reglets rang with rafter-look,  
And ruglings rolled on velvet tracks.  

Beware the Furniturion, dear!  
The splinter-snout with swivel jaw!  
Beware the clackling chandelier,  
And shun the brambled bureau-gnaw!  

He took his sandy mallet up,  
Long time the lumber-foe he sought;  
So rested he by rocker-cup,  
And pondered screws of studious thought.  

And, as in jigsaw muse he lay,  
The Furniturion, knobs aflare,  
Came clumping through the parquet way  
And huffed its creaky, oaken air!  

Smack-whack! and crack-clack! back it reeled—  
The reglet flashed in varnish light.  
He left it splintered, hinge-unsealed,  
And packed its planks in boxes tight.  

“O hast thou slayed the Furniturion?  
Come brace thy bolts upon my chest!  
O chiming joy! Upholsteron!”  
He jigged in foam and feathered zest.  

’Twas flimber-fent in Furnishbrook,  
The deskly drawers dreamt in wax;  
All reglets rang with rafter-look,  
And ruglings rolled on velvet tracks.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "old piton scar". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Old Piton Scar

’Twas crevice-dark, and the knobble stones  
Did scrample-scree along the char;  
All whindle-whacked were the flinter bones  
That ringed the old Piton Scar.  

“Beware the Piton!” the elder cried,  
“That craggle-gouge that gnaws the moon!  
Bewatch the rift where belchers bide  
And glimbers croon their rune!”  

He took his shimmer-shankled blade;  
Long time the ferrow foe he sought—  
So rested he by the flamblent shade  
And moused in thinksome thought.  

And as in nervid doubt he stood,  
The Piton Scar, with maulful might,  
Came scronking up through screet and mud,  
Its fumar eyes a-light!  

One, two! One, two! and through and through  
The shimmer blade went snicker-snar;  
He clove its shriek, and, smeared with glue,  
He quelled the Piton Scar.  

“And hast thou flain the Piton dread?  
Come, clasp thy hands, my gleesome star!  
O flimsy day! Caloop! Caled!”  
He chortled o’er the scar.  

’Twas crevice-dark, and the knobble stones  
Did scrample-scree along the char;  
All whindle-whacked were the flinter bones  
That ringed the old Piton Scar.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "loom shuttle pick". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Loomshuttle Pick

’Twas spoolish, and the weavyskeins  
  Did twindle-twist along the beam;  
All frabrous were the bobbinqueens,  
  And weftlings wove a seam.  

“Beware the Loomshuttle, my child!  
  The toothedy tines, the snapping clack!  
Beware the knotkink snarl so wild,  
  And shun the snarling slack!”  

He took his warpish reed in hand;  
  Long time the twilling foe he sought—  
So rested he by heddle-tree,  
  And stood awhile in thought.  

And, as in woofish muse he bobbed,  
  The Loomshuttle, with eyes of pick,  
Came flicker-flack through bolted shed,  
  And clattered quick-a-quick!  

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
  The beat-up blade went slicker-slack!  
He left it dead, and with its head  
  Went skeining back alack.  

“And hast thou slain the Loomshuttle?  
  Come weftish lad, bumbrace, bumbrace!  
O wollop day! Caroon! Hurray!”  
  He twirled a warpful pace.  

’Twas spoolish, and the weavyskeins  
  Did twindle-twist along the beam;  
All frabrous were the bobbinqueens,  
  And weftlings wove a seam.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "tinsmith stake song". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Tinsmith Stake-Song

’Twas glimber-dawn, and the tinsmith stakes
Did clink and clatter-clang;
All whindle-bent were the coppery quakes,
And the bruzzle-bellows sang.

“Beware the Stake-Song, smithy lad!
The trundle-tine that shrills and shakes!
Beware the snicker-snapping gad,
And shun the sputter-spark flakes!”

He took his hickory hammer up;
Long time the frettish foe he sought—
Then, resting by a solder-cup,
He dreamed in doodle-thought.

And, as in rumble-pose he stood,
The Stake-Song, rampant, roared its tune,
Blorfing through brassish bolted wood,
By flare of furnace-moon!

One, two!  One, two!  And through and through
The hickory hammer went wick-whack!
He split the song in twain, and drew
Its tinny echo back.

“O frabjous clang!  Ker-clang!  Hooray!”
He chimed his anviled joy.
Then back he strode through flicker’d spray,
A smelt-bespattered boy.

’Twas glimber-dawn, and the tinsmith stakes
Still clink and clatter-clang;
Each ember hums, the foundry wakes—
So ends the Stake-Song’s fang.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pietra dura inlay". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Pietra Durawocky

’Twas malachite, and marble mares
   Did flisk and flurry down the way;
All agate were the onyx airs,
   And cameo winds at play.

“Beware the Durawock, my child!
   The grit-toothed beast of glue and grout!
Beware the tigrine tiger-eye,
   And jade-jaw’d jasper snout!”

He took his granite-graven blade;
   Long time the lapis foe he sought—
So rested he by jasper tree,
   And stood in champlevé thought.

And, as in quartzish qualm he mused,
   The Durawock, with eyes of gneiss,
Came lurching through the marbling wood,
   In layered, lustrous slice!

One, two! One, two! The chisel flew!
   The lappish blade went snicker-snack!
He cleft it clean from slate to sheen
   And bore the trophy back.

“O gleamish day! Pietray! Pietray!”
   He caperquartzily began;
“Carve forth inlay, let lapid stay—
   My son’s a pietra man!”

’Twas malachite, and marble mares
   Did flisk and flurry down the way;
All agate were the onyx airs,
   And cameo winds at play.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blue hour on snow". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Blue Hour on Snow

’Twas glimber-blue, and the sniver flakes
Did whimple-wamp across the wold;
All squinkle-glazed were brummel brakes,
And frostwigs dripped with cold.

“Beware the Bleakling, child of dusk!
The gloamgale’s nip, the driftling’s bite!
Beware the moonmire’s cobalt musk,
That haunts the hush of night!”

He snatched his shimmer-sapphire brand;
Long time the numble foe he sought—
So trimbly stepped o’er pearl-piled land,
Through flinter flumes of thought.

And, as in shuddered hush he stood,
The Bleakling—looming, wraithing low—
Came wivver-weaving through the wood,
Blue-breathing on the snow!

Slish-slash! flash-dash! the sapphire sang!
The chill thing shrieked in swirling glow;
Then down it slumped with bitter clang,
And thawful tears did flow.

“O braveling boy, come prance thy way!”
Cried voices warm in afterglow.
“Rejoice, for now the gloam turns gray—
Blue hour upon the snow!”

’Tis glimber-blue; the sniver flakes
Still whimple-wamp across the wold;
Yet gleamful hearts and hearthful aches
Beat bright against the cold.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "crosstie creosote scent". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Crosstie Creosote Scent

’Twas rankle-dark on the railborn way,
  And the crooncrabs crost and clanged;
All swillowy smelt the dusking day,
  While the tar-taut ties were twanged.

Beware the Creosote, my child!
  The ooze that oaks the ties!
Beware the Tracklebeast so wild,
  With smoke-smudged, cinder eyes!

He sniffed the night with nostril keen;
  His sniffer-sword he drew.
By candlemoon and rippling green
  The railsong thrummed askew.

Plunk-plank!  Plunk-plank!  The clatter-clang
  Went skirling down the line!
He heard the Creosote’s dank-drip fang
  And felt its fumes entwine.

One, two!  One, two!  And through and through
  His sniffer-sword went snick!
He cleft the puffing ooze in two,
  Then tramped the ties, heartsick.

“And hast thou slain the Creosote?
  Come rail-arm, lad, to me!”
O blither joy!  O gleeful throat!
  He tooted mightily.

’Tis rankle-dark on the railborn way,
  And the crooncrabs crost and clanged;
All swillowy smelt the dusking day,
  While the tar-taut ties were twanged.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "balance spring collet". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Balance Spring Collet

’Twas tacit-torque, and the splice-thrum gears
Did whipple and whindle the crown;
All fribble were the pivon spheres,
And the ratchets raxled round.

“Beware the Balance Spring Collet, child!
The jivel-jaws that creak and clamp!
Beware the tick-tang stutter wild,
And shun the stamp-torque’s cramp!”

He took his chronic saber-steel:
Long time the quiver-quake he sought—
So rested he by the ruby wheel
And timed in clocket thought.

And, as in syncop’d dreams he stood,
The Collet came with snip-snap gleam,
Ratcheting through the brassen wood,
By mainspring’s woundful seam!

Tick-tack! Tick-tack! And clickety-click!
The saber-steel went slice and sway!
He snipped its clamp in half a tick,
And cogless rolled away.

“O hast thou clamped the Collet grim?
Come, windful lad, to balance hall!
O marvelous beat! O cadence trim!”
He chrono-laughed in drawl.

’Twas tacit-torque, and the splice-thrum gears
Did whipple and whindle the crown;
All fribble were the pivon spheres,
And the ratchets raxled round.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pantograph arcing blue". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Pantograph Arcing Blue

’Twas gloaming-grey, and trolley trams
Did flange and shimmer through the hue;
All drooping were the cable-clams,
The pantograph arcing blue.

“Beware the Sparkingram, my child!
The volts that crack, the jaws they brew!
Beware the fierce Electrowild
And shun its thunder-strew.”

He grasped his carbon-shafted pole;
Long time the zigging foe he sought—
So rested he by copper knoll
And pondered watt on thought.

And as in whirrful muse he stood,
The Sparkingram, with eyes aflame,
Came whizzle-whumping through the wood
And crackled as it came!

Zap-zip! Zing-zap! The ebon rod
Went snicker-snack with ozone roar;
He left it scorched, a smoking clod,
And lugged its husk once more.

“And hast thou slew the Sparkingram?
Come surge within my arms, dear brew!
Oh frabjous day! Ker-switch! Ker-clam!”
He chortled, sparking too.

’Twas gloaming-grey, and trolley trams
Still flanged and shimmered through the hue;
All resting were the cable-clams,
The pantograph arcing blue.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Murmuration over Stubble

’Twas stubble-drift, and foison fields
   Lay scraggle-bare and brown;
The snergling frost on hay-rake shields
   Came twizzle-whimper down.

Beware the Murmurock, my dear,
   With swirls of sooty hue!
Beware the drumble-dartling sheer
   That fliskers in the blue!

He gripped his bramble-knotted stake,
   His heart a hoppive drum;
Along the thresher-ridges' wake
   He strode in grumblish glum.

And as he stood in stubbled gloom,
   The Murmurock in flight—
A murmuration over broom,
   A loom of living night—

Came swizz-a-swarm! and flit-a-flawn!
   With thousand-thrumbling beat;
They twistled wide, they twizzled drawn,
   They curled in curving skeet.

Whiff-whaff! whiff-whaff! the stake he swung,
   Star-scorching through the dusk;
He clove the cloud-knot’s knotted tongue
   And snapped its sooty husk.

“O shimmer-boy, thy stroke is bold!”
   The threshmen cried in cheer;
“The stubble’s safe; the skies unfold
   With gladsome, glimmer clear!”

’Twas stubble-drift, and foison fields
   Lay still beneath the moon;
No shadow-swarm on hay-rake shields,
   But hush in harvest rune.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pewter inlay ribbon". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Pewterlay Ribbon

’Twas glimber-grey, and the pewterlay
Did prindle inlay through the loom;
All frindle were the natter-frays,
And brabbling winks went bloom.

“Beware the Ribbon-snap, my sprout,
The ratch that frays and frills!
Beware the gleaming Guttergout,
And mind the clinking quills!”

He took his tinsel–twisted blade;
Long time the twizzle foe he sought—
So lounged he by the dappled shade
And dreamt in loopèd thought.

And, while in woofish muse he lay,
The Ribbon-snap, with ribbon roar,
Came prancing through the pewterlay
And twizzled as before!

Snick-snack! The silver slicer sang!
The brabbling beast fell shear;
He left it limp, with looper clang,
And stowed its gleaming gear.

“Come, spangle child! Seek hearth and board!”
He tripped through gloam and glide.
O hastish joy! O frindled chord!
He flang the prize beside.

’Twas glimber-grey, and the pewterlay
Still prindled inlay through the loom;
All frindle were the natter-frays,
And brabbling winks went bloom.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "linocut brayer chatter". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Linocut Brayer Chatter

’Twas pressil, and the linocuts  
Did bray and chatter through the plane;  
All inkling were the brittle ruts,  
And the rag rollers left a stain.  

“Beware the Brayer-beast, my child!  
The jaws that press! The claws that clack!  
Beware the chatter, sharp and wild,  
And shun the guzzling inky black!”  

He took his cromfy gouge in hand;  
Long time the blocksome foe he sought—  
So rested he by Drypoint Stand  
And pondered stamping thought.  

And, as in scruffy muse he lay,  
The Brayer-beast, with eyes aflare,  
Came clacking through the chatter-spray,  
And gurpled inky air.  

One, two! One, two! And skew and slew!  
The cromfy gouge went nickety-gnack!  
He split it dead; and, bleeding glue,  
It fell with brayer crack.  

“And hast thou slain the Brayer brute?  
Come, pressy boy, thine fame resounds!  
O clappy day! Kaloo kalhoot!”  
He twirled in inky bounds.  

’Twas pressil, and the linocuts  
Did bray and chatter through the plane;  
All inkling were the brittle ruts,  
And the rag rollers left a stain.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "quarter‑sawn shimmer". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Quarter-Sawn Shimmer

’Twas shop-light, and the curly grains  
Did flip and flutter on the board;  
All flindy-flecked the ribboned planes,  
And glossle-gloams a-hurtle poured.  

“Beware the Quarter-sawn Shimmer, boy!  
The glare that glints and glieves so bright!  
Beware the fangle-fangled ploy  
Of swirling chattoque-drifted weaves!”  

He took his burnish-whettle plane;  
Long time the toggling wood he sought—  
So rested he by resin tree  
And stood awhile in deep-shod thought.  

And, as in wimbly muse he stood,  
The Shimmer, shashing bright with gleam,  
Came glisking through the rippled wood,  
And flickled whirry shades of cream!  

One-two! One-two! And through and through  
His verber-scraper went whack-whack!  
He cleft its glare in flinders two,  
And sent its lustre lurching back.  

“And hast thou quelled the Shimmer fair?  
Come claspful, child, unto my vise!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callair!”  
He warbled, triple-woodsome-nice.  

’Twas shop-light, and the curly grains  
Did flip and flutter on the board;  
All flindy-flecked the ribboned planes,  
And glossle-gloams a-hurtle poured.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Blued Screw in a Movement

’Twas tickletide, when cogful gears  
Did whirr and whuzzle through the frame;  
All clickle was the mainspring’s cheer,  
And escapewheels aflame.  

“Beware the Blued Screw, child of mine!  
The sapphire-thread, the bite so tight!  
Beware the flutter-clutch, and shun  
The ratchety Fobberwight!”  

He took his driver bold in hand;  
Long time the ticksome foe he sought—  
So rested he by Balance-Tree  
And timed a while in thought.  

And as in troven dream he wound,  
The Blued Screw, flash-blue and keen,  
Came whistling through the movement’s sound  
And shim-sham slid between!  

One—two! One—two! And through and through  
His wrenchy steel went snick-snack-snore!  
He left it dead, and with its head  
He clacked and clicked once more.  

“Hast thou unscrewed the Blued Screw?  
Come grip, my boy, recoil with joy!”  
“O ratchet day! Hooray! Hooray!”  
He chimed in alloy.  

’Twas tickletide; the cogful gears  
Now hummed in even-tempered grace.  
The movement rang with merry cheer,  
And parts clicked back in place.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "parrel bead on a gaff". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Parrel Bead on a Gaff

‘Twas bluster-night, the whelming seas  
Did whirple and woggle in the draff;  
All splyce and spars spun snickerwise,  
A parrel bead on a gaff.  

“Beware the Tiderake, my mate!  
The croon that clacks, the boom that bites!  
Beware the slackjawed Bowsprit’s hate,  
And shun the spry Spritsail-kites!”  

He took his belaying blade in hand;  
Long time the foamy foe he sought—  
So rested he by deadeye tree  
And pondered moon-born thought.  

But as he brimmed by bilgey brink,  
The Tiderake with eyes of brine  
Came rollythump through rimpled drink,  
And burbled down the line!  

One-two! One-two! and through and through  
His belay blade went snicker-snack!  
He left it bled, and with its head  
He clambered starboard back.  

“O hast thou quelled the Tiderake?  
Come clasp me close, my stalwart staff!  
O frabjous tide! Kaloo, kallake!”  
A parrel bead on a gaff.  

‘Twas bluster-night, the whelming seas  
Did whirple and woggle in the draff;  
All splyce and spars spun snickerwise,  
A parrel bead on a gaff.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sourdough levain autolyse". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Sourdough-Lavain Autolyse

’Twas bubbly, and the gluten-glibs
   Did gyre and gimble in the bowl;
All flosky were the crumbly cribs,
   And rye-wraiths roamed in drole.

“Beware the Levain, my cook!
   The tang that bites, the fizz that foams!
Beware the Dough-devouring Glouk,
   And shun the slackish gloams!”

He took his crimping blade in hand;
   Long time the foamy foe he sought—
So rested he by proofing stand
   And kneaded deep in thought.

And, as in leathern proof he lay,
   The Levain, loomish, light, and loud,
Came flumping through the tacky clay,
   Fermenting in its cloud!

Whack—snitch! Whack—snitch! And, with a flick,
   The blade went snicker-snack!
He split it swift, he sponged it thick,
   Then turned, barm-laden, back.

“Hast risen well?” “Breadacious boy!
   O crumbly cheer, O crusty grace!”
He chortled in his yeasty joy,
   And braced the baking place.

’Twas bubbly, and the gluten-glibs
   Did gyre and gimble in the bowl;
All flosky were the crumbly cribs,
   And rye-wraiths roamed in drole.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sashiko boro patch". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Sashiko Boro Patch

’Twas frumpy-morn, and the thready feys  
Did rifflestitch the fray;  
All raggle-torn the boro-born  
In sashikoozling gray.  

Beware the Tatternag, my dear,  
The snip-snap, snurl, and snatch!  
Beware the ravel-ripping sneer  
Of Sashiko Boro Patch!  

He grasped his needle-sabre keen;  
Long time the tatters foe,  
He quested there by selvage bare  
Where warp-winds wibble-woe.  

And as he hemmed in hushful dreams,  
The Tatternag, so slick,  
Came fluffle-flap through shuttle’s gap,  
All frayful, quick-a-flick!  

Zip-zap! Zip-zap! Through weft and wrap,  
His blade of thread did catch;  
He snick-snack sewed the ragstack foe—  
O Sashiko Boro Patch!  

“Thrice spliced are we! Come prance with glee!”  
He chirpled, bold and bright.  
Then stitch by stitch the seams grew rich,  
And frayed dusk mended night.  

’Twas frumpy-morn, and the thready feys  
Did rifflestitch the fray;  
All raggle-torn no more were worn—  
The cloth danced warpwise gay.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "nixie tube warm glow". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Nixiglow

’Twas ohmic and the filagroved wires,  
Did flick and fuzzle in the loam;  
All glimmer were the cybrant fires,  
And bitsyn sparks intone.  

“Beware the Nixiglow, my child!  
The tubes that hum, the digits bright!  
Beware the cathode-sputter wild,  
The amber thrumming light!”  

He took his solder-iron blade;  
Long time the quartzsome foe he sought—  
So rested he by breadboard shade  
And lounged in lull of thought.  

And, as in ohmful dream he stood,  
The Nixiglow, with font of flame,  
Came whirring through the glassy wood,  
Its numbers pipping tame!  

One two! One two! And through and through  
The copper blade went snicker-snack!  
He cleft its leads, and with its deeds  
He marched the chassis back.  

“And hast thou slain the Nixiglow?  
Come to my bench, thou sparkish boy!  
O lumious day! Flux-flux, hurray!”  
He chortled in his joy.  

’Twas ohmic and the filagroved wires,  
Did flick and fuzzle in the loam;  
All glimmer were the cybrant fires,  
And bitsyn sparks intone.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "fishtail gouge sweep". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Fishtail Gouge Sweep

’Twas gutter-glum, and the fishtail flutes
Did skeeve and squamper through the seep;  
All gory were the gouge-root brutes,  
And the winderloons did sweep.  

“Beware the Fishtail-Gouge-Sweep, my sprout!  
The jaws that nick, the sweep that flay!  
Beware the ragger-rake, and shun  
The dread kerf-gobbling fay!”  

He grasped his trusty chiselblade;  
Long time the knurly foe he sought—  
So rested he by the strop-sharp tree  
And tuned his turning thought.  

And, as in muffish muse he stood,  
The Fishtail-Gouge-Sweep, wild and grim,  
Came scrabbawrenching through the wood,  
And burbled edge to rim!  

Snick-snack! His chiselblade went click!  
He skewed and skewered it in two;  
He left it dead, and with its head  
He stropped his steel anew.  

“And hast thou slain the Gouge-Sweep beast?  
Come to my bench, embrace my neck!  
O frabjous day! Kerchunk! ker-chey!”  
He clacked with mallet-check.  

’Twas gutter-glum, and the fishtail flutes  
Did skeeve and squamper through the seep;  
All gory were the gouge-root brutes,  
And the winderloons did sweep.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "letter kept in a cedar box". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Letterkeep in the Cedar Box

’Twas cedarnoon, and the whittling whorls  
Did creakle-crack in fragrant gloom;  
All resin-slick the dovetail curls,  
While hushlings brimmed the room.  

“Beware the Letterkeep, my sprout!  
The vellum-gnaw, the spatter-sprite!  
Beware the whisk of hush-about,  
And Ink-Moth’s midnight flight!”  

He primed his quirrel-quill of yore;  
Long time that fretful foe he trailed—  
So perched he near the cedar door,  
And sniffed where secrets ailed.  

And, as by stamp and seal he knelt,  
The Letterkeep, in rustledox,  
Came skitter-flit with camphor pelt  
From out the silent box!  

Snap-scritch! Snap-scritch! And scrabble-scratch!  
The quirrel-quill went snick-snack-sneer!  
He scuffed the scrawl, he won the match,  
And canned the cur of fear.  

“Hast thou subdued the Letterkeep?  
Come rest with me, my brambled boy!  
O blithsome day! Karumble deep!”  
He crowed in cedar joy.  

’Twas cedarnoon, and the whittling whorls  
Still creakle-crack in fragrant gloom;  
The letter sleeps in dovetail swirls,  
And secrets seed the room.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "Morse straight key click". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Morse Straight Key Click

’Twas brassy-bent in etherloom,  
The ditty-dahs went click ’n’ clack;  
All bramble-hiss’d the hertzwave fume,  
And tickle-sparks knap-back.  

“Beware the Clatterwock, my child!  
The buzzlefret that thrums and nips!  
Beware the gurglish Static wild,  
And shun the gloamy grips!”  

He took his trusty sounder blade;  
Long time the quavery foe he sought—  
So rested he by coilshade tree,  
And tuned in thinkish thought.  

And, as in hummy rest he keyed,  
The Clatterwock, with flashly click,  
Came zootling through the scritchy reed,  
And fluster-flang’d too quick!  

One, two! One, two! And dit-dah-dit!  
The sounder blade went tick-tack-tick!  
He left it mute, in sparker split,  
And bore away the click.  

“Hast thou declick’d the Clatterwock?  
Come thrumful arms, my keyed-up boy!  
O fulsome day! Dah-dit! Dah-dock!”  
He chortled in his joy.  

’Twas brassy-bent in etherloom,  
The ditty-dahs went click ’n’ clack;  
Still bramble-hiss’d the hertzwave fume,  
And tickle-sparks knap-back.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "fiddle rosin dust". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Fiddle-Rosin Ruckus

’Twas sizzle-sawn of afternoon,  
When rosine motes did glide and gust;  
All quirker-queaked the bowstring tune,  
And drimbles droned in dust.  

“Beware the Fiddle-Ros, my child!  
The screeching scree, the scratchy flight!  
Beware the rasple-claw and wild  
That skrees across the night.”  

He took his twisty timbre stick;  
Long time the twinkling chord he sought—  
So rested he by knurly brick  
And tuned in tinkling thought.  

And, as in uffish muse he bowed,  
The Fiddle-Ros, with wailish gleam,  
Came whiffling through the rosin cloud  
And rasped within his dream!  

Snick-snack! The horsehair cracked and clung!  
The jingling notes went crash-ka-thrum!  
He left it limp, its echoes sung,  
He hummed a humble hum.  

“And hast thou slain the Fiddle-Ros?  
Come scrape the strings, my gleesome boy!  
O frabjous play! Ker-swish! Ker-slos!  
He canters forth in joy.”  

’Twas sizzle-sawn of afternoon,  
When rosine motes did glide and gust;  
All quirker-queaked the bowstring tune,  
And drimbles droned in dust.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plane iron camber". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Plane Iron Camber

’Twas cloggy eve, the splindish slints
Did whicker-scrape o’er curly timber;
All shorple keen were shaver-flints,
And plane-iron-camber.

“Beware the Tear-out fiend, my child!
The grain that claws, the knot that hammers!
Beware the snatch-back, ragged-wild,
And shun the skew-tooth clammers!”

He braced his bearded smoother tight;
Long time the whiffling pith he sought—
So rested he by lamplight tree
And mulled a marmly thought.

And, as in rumkin muse he stood,
The Tear-out, gribble-gnashing raw,
Came sworpling through the grainy wood,
And furrowed as it gnawed!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The cambered edge went snicker-snacker!
He left it peeled; then off he wheeled
With shavings in his knacker.

“Hast planed it true, my curly knight?
Come to my bench, my brilly stamper!
O chipper day! Ker-curl! Hooray!”
He whooped his iron camber.

’Twas cloggy eve, the splindish slints
Did whicker-scrape o’er curly timber;
All shorple keen were shaver-flints,
And plane-iron-camber.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "orin bell hum". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Orin Bell Hum

’Twas loondrift eve, the crinkled moons  
Spun widdershin through clarry sky;  
All bramblebeasts on flumber dunes  
Snootled soft while nightsong sighed.  

Beware the Orin Bell, my child!  
Its jang-crown clangs, its hum-heart thrums;  
Its tintle lure grows niggling wild,  
Its jimmer-jaw unbuttons drums.  

He took his whiffle-spear in hand;  
Long time the glimsome foe he sought—  
So rested he by frindle strand  
And pondered on a piffled thought.  

And as in snuzzle muse he stood,  
The Orin Bell, with murk-slow flow,  
Came chuffling through the shadow wood  
And drizzled dreams of amber glow.  

One—two! One—two! And through and through  
The whiffle-spear went nick-snack-snear!  
He snicked its chime, he stilled its coo,  
And whurled its hush upon the air.  

“Come, cush, my boy! Huzzah, hooray!”  
They gabbled home in peal and strum.  
“O frabjous day! Caloo, calay!”  
He quelled the Orin Bell of Hum.  

Now bramblebeasts at gloaming’s crest  
Still merribound in dewdrop sun.  
Yet, eerielate, the dusk is blessed  
By faint, far Orin Bell…hum…

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "quenching brine hiss". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Quenching Brine-Hiss

’Twas brankling tide, and murmy waves  
Did sloodle through the moonlit foam;  
All frimbly were the kelp-gloomed caves,  
Where cruston whelks made slither-home.  

“Beware the Brine-Hiss, child of spray!  
The jaws that glut, the gills that gleam!  
Beware the Quenching surge’s sway,  
And shun the gulmy drift-stream!”  

He grasped his silver-dritchel spear;  
Long time the foamy foe he sought—  
He tarried by a scudgy pier  
And ponder-plumed in tide-tossed thought.  

And, as in briny brood he stood,  
The Brine-Hiss, riddling slick with shriek,  
Rose gurgling from the teal-green flood,  
Salt fury bubbling past its beak!  

Snik-shrak! With whelm and warp and whirl  
He smote it through the swirling foam;  
The quenching brine hiss quit its curl  
And sank beneath the coral-loam.  

“Come, gladsome son, untide your dread!  
So sings the surf of valor won.”  
He brought the slorping helm of red,  
And brine-bells chimed their tiding-sun.  

’Twas brankling tide, yet murmy waves  
Now sloodle soft o’er tranquil foam;  
All rested are the kelp-lit caves—  
For Brine-Hiss sleeps in salt-dark gloam.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "badger knot bloom". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Badgerknot Bloom

’Twas fuzzle-frond in dingle dell,  
The bruzzy badgers bumbled bright;  
All knotter-snarled the briar-smell,  
And bloomlings laughed in light.  

Beware the Badgerknot, my child!  
The tufted claws, the snicker-snout!  
Beware the bloomish glare and wild,  
The petal-paw’d devout!  

He took his glimsy shears in hand;  
Long time the quibble foe he sought—  
So rested he by Waggledy tree  
And pondered blooming knot.  

And, as in knookish thought he stood,  
The Badgerknot, with wheezle-whisk,  
Came burbling through the bramblish wood,  
All fluster-fuzzed and brisk!  

Clip-clap! Clip-clap! And snip-snap-snuck!  
The glimsy shears went snitter-snack!  
He cleft its bloom and knotted plume,  
Then galumphing scampered back.  

“O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”  
They fluffled in their glee!  
’Twas fuzzle-frond in dingle dell,  
And calm the knooklings be.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "nib tine micro‑mesh". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Nib-Tine Micro-Mesh

’Twas biroglime, and the feathrous quills  
Did swink and swurl within the scribe;  
All inky were the drippling frills,  
And blorpy blotters bribe.  

“Beware the Nib-Tine Micro-Mesh,  
The gears that grate, the shears that shred!  
Beware the scribbling Bounder-fresh,  
And shun the Paper-munching Zed!”  

He took his carbon-cleaving pen;  
Long time the quinsome foe he sought—  
So rested he by Desk-tree den,  
And thunked in printless thought.  

And, as in ambi-dreamish pose  
He cogitated, plume unsheathed,  
The Nib-Tine, with its meshy rows,  
Came quivering, ink-wreath’d!  

Splick-splat! Splick-splat! Through vell and vell  
The pen-point flashed with scrawling flare!  
He left it torn, the mesh forlorn,  
And filed with flourish rare.  

“And hast thou slain the Micro-Mesh?  
Come, scrawlful child, finagle free!  
O callooh, callay!” he squinkled fresh,  
In paper-pompety glee.  

’Twas biroglime, and the feathrous quills  
Did swink and swurl within the scribe;  
All inky were the drippling frills,  
And blorpy blotters bribe.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "krenovian plane throat". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Krenovian Plane-Throat

’Twas glimsy-gruntle in the wending shade,  
The krenzle toves were brangling sly;  
All frowsy were the drimmel blades,  
And the groffled grooms did cry.  

“Beware the Plane-Throat, child of knair!  
The jaws that cleave, the voice that rends!  
Beware the snarplered Krenov snare,  
And shun the thrungle-bending ends!”  

He took his quimsome vorpal stave;  
Long time the plorple foe he sought—  
So rested he by Brindle Cave,  
And stood a while in snarlish thought.  

And, as in gumpy thought he stood,  
The Plane-Throat, frame on thunder borne,  
Came flundering through the knurple wood,  
With bluster-blades and bronchial horn!  

One, two! Each whacking he did make,  
The vorpal stave went swish and swing;  
He snicked the air with snabbled quake,  
And frudged it dead with final ring.  

“And hast thou slain the Plane-Throat dread?  
Come, prangle arms, my gleesome boy!  
O flummish day! Krenoo! Krened!”  
He chortled in his sprockled joy.  

’Twas glimsy-gruntle in the wending shade,  
The krenzle toves were brangling sly;  
All frowsy were the drimmel blades,  
And the groffled grooms did cry.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "rain on a tin roof". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Patterplip

’Twas clangly eve, and pluvious drops  
Did plitter-plotter on the tin;  
All splishysplanks the gutter hops,  
And drabbly dribbles din.  

“Beware the Patterplip, my child!  
The drip that drums the rafter’s lip!  
Beware the clank-clash Clatterwild,  
And shun the Dripperdrip!”  

He took his twinkling bucket-blade;  
Long time the splattery foe he sought—  
So rested he beneath the shade,  
And thunk the thunk of thought.  

And, as in drowsy drift he lurked,  
The Patterplip, with plickish tune,  
Came plubbling through the splangly murk  
And rattled ’neath the moon!  

Plip-plap! Plip-plap! And splangy-splosh!  
The tin roof rang from ridge to root;  
He swung his pail with clank and closh,  
And stilled the clamorous brute.  

“O frabjous hush! Calloo, calluff!”  
He crowed beneath the softened eaves.  
The Patterplip lay puddled fluff  
Among the soggy leaves.  

’Twas clangly eve, and pluvious drops  
Did plitter-plotter on the tin;  
All splishysplanks the gutter hops,  
And drabbly dribbles din.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sencha kyusu drip". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Sencha Kyusowocky

’Twas leafmerg dusk, and slithy steamers  
Did gyre and gimble through the steep;  
All murmy were the frothing dreamers,  
And sencha kyusu drip.  

“Beware the Kyusowock, my child,  
The hinge-hinged spout that hiss and clack!  
Beware the Bitterbrew so wild,  
And shun the tetchy Tippleback!”  

He took his paper-filtered sword;  
Long time the cafeful foe he sought.  
So rested he by matcha gourd,  
And sipped in whispish thought.  

And, as in slurping muse he stood,  
The Kyusowock, with swirl of steam,  
Came glooping through the copperwood  
And burbled in caffeine.  

One, two! One, two! And swirl and brew!  
The filter-foil went clish and clap!  
He left it steeped and stinging through,  
And yanked the drizzled flap.  

“And hast thou slain the Kyusowock?  
Come stir, my boy, upon the mat!  
O cha-cha day! Kaloo, kachock!”  
He gulped his sipful vat.  

’Twas leafmerg dusk, and slithy steamers  
Did gyre and gimble through the steep;  
All murmy were the frothing dreamers,  
And sencha kyusu drip.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "split‑grade enlarger burn". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Split-Grade Enlarger Burn

’Twas darkroomeet, and the slithy trays
Did swash and swizzle in the bath;
All hazywere the bromi-rays,
And safelamps hummed in wrath.

“Beware the Enlarger, light-shy son,
With split-grade jaws that twist and turn!
Beware the burn-beaked Dodgigon,
And shun the fogsome Earn!”

He took his fibre-tongs in hand;
Long time the shadeful foe he sought—
So rested he by rinse-aid tree
And stood a-while in thought.

And, as in grainful thought he bent,
The Enlarger scrolled with gutter-gurn,
Whiffling through fumes magnificent,
A-seeking prints to burn!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The focus-lever went snick-snack!
He split the grade and, dauntless-made,
He drove the shadows back.

“And hast thou quelled the Enlarger dread?
Come, clamp thy proof, my silverling!
O flashsome day! Safelight hurray!”
He chortled in his fling.

’Twas darkroomeet, and the slithy trays
Did swash and swizzle in the bath;
All hazywere the bromi-rays,
And safelamps hummed in wrath.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "kiridashi scribe line". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Kiridashi Scribe-Line

’Twas bevel-bright, and the slithy shavings  
Did whipple-whurr across the grain;  
All knurly were the workbench havings,  
And splinters grokled vain.

“Beware the Kiridashi, lad!  
The spine-sharp steel, the humming edge!  
Beware the scribe-line’s haunting gad,  
The ghost along the ledge!”

He took his strop-borne barrow blade;  
Long time the groffish seam he sought—  
So paused beneath the lambert shade,  
And carved himself a thought.

And, as in stillish muse he knelt,  
The Kiridashi, squat and sly,  
Came whisper-quick through cedar pelt,  
With brambled glare and gimlet eye!

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The paring point went snick-snack-shine!  
He left it rent, and with its dent  
He etched the scribe-line sign.

“And hast thou slain the Kiridash?  
Come to my arms, my rabbet boy!  
O tenon day! Ker-vash! Ker-splash!”  
He chortled, full of joy.

’Twas bevel-bright, and the slithy shavings  
Did whipple-whurr across the grain;  
All knurly were the workbench havings,  
And splinters grokled vain.
